metadata.title: Metal oxides as photo catalysts: Modified sodium tantalate as catalyst for photo reduction of carbon dioxide

S2468-8231(17)30613-2 10.1016/j.mcat.2017.11.021 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns for neat and modified catalysts (a) NaTaO3 (b) LNTO, (c) N/LNTO, (d) Fe/LNTO, (e) Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Diffuse reflectance spectra of neat and modified NaTaO3 catalysts (a) LNTO, (b) NaTaO3, (c) Fe/LNTO, (d) N/LNTO, (e) Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) SEM image and (b) EDXA spectrum for NaTaO3 photo catalyst. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) SEM image and (b) EDXA spectrum for Fe-N/LNTO photo catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Transmission Electron Microscopic images for (a) LNTO (b) Fe-N/LNTO (c) SAED for Fe-N/LNTO (d) HRTEM for Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 High resolution XP spectra of Na 1s, Ta 4d and O 1s for neat and modified catalysts (a) NaTaO3 (b) LNTO, (c) N/LNTO, (d) Fe/LNTO, (e) Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 High resolution XP spectra of La 3d [A], Ta 4f [B] for neat and modified catalysts (a) Fe-N/LNTO, (b) Fe/LNTO, (c) N/LNTO, (d) LNTO, (e) NaTaO3. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 High resolution XPS spectra of N 1s [A] and Fe 2p [B] for neat and modified catalysts (a) N/LNTO, (b) Fe-N/LNTO, (c) Fe/LNTO. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Photo luminescence spectra for neat and modified NaTaO3 catalysts (a) NaTaO3, (b) LNTO, c) N/LNTO, (d) Fe/LNTO, (e) Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Trends in photo catalytic activity for CO2 reduction with alkaline medium - Time On stream plots - (a) NaTaO3, (b) Fe-N/LNTO. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Comparison of photocatalytic activity for neat and modified catalysts after 20hrs of irradiation: (a) NaTaO3 (b) LNTO, (c) N/LNTO, (d) Fe/LNTO, (e) Fe-N/LNTO. [C1 – C1 carbon products, C2 – C2 carbon products, TC – Total Carbon products]. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 VBM and CBM energy levels of LNTO and Fe-N modified catalysts. Rao b Nettem V. Choudary b Kandasamy Thirunavukkarasu a Konda Ramasamy Krishnamurthy a Balasubramanian Viswanathan a ⁎ a National Centre for Catalysis Research, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai, 600036, India National Centre for Catalysis Research Indian Institute of Technology Madras Chennai 600036 India b HPCL Green R and D Centre, Hoskote, Bengaluru-560067, India HPCL Green R and D Centre Hoskote Bengaluru 560067 India c Department of Chemistry, Thiagarajar College, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai-625021, India Department of Chemistry Thiagarajar College Madurai Kamaraj University Madurai 625021 India ⁎ Corresponding author at National Centre for Catalysis Research (NCCR), Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai 600036, India Graphical abstract Modifications in the electronic levels of NaTaO3 by doping with La3+, N and Fe3+. Sodium tantalate (NaTaO3), a typical mixed metal oxide with orthorhombic structure, has been modified by incorporation of lanthana (LaxNa(1−x)TaO(3+y) or LNTO), followed by doping/co-doping with N and Fe3+, with the objective of improving visible light absorption and photo physical properties. XRD and XPS results reveal that La3+ occupies Na+ ion sites, Fe3+ ions Ta5+ ion sites and N the O2− ion sites, possibly as N3− in the tantalate matrix. Incorporation of the dopants in the tantalate matrix has been confirmed by SEM-EDXA and STEM-EDS elemental mapping and surface composition analysis by XPS. Fe and N co-doping in tantalate matrix results in the narrowing of the band gap due to the creation of additional energy levels within the band gap and consequently, visible light absorption. Presence of Fe3+ and La3+ dopants in the tantalate lattice ensures electro-neutrality. Efficient charge trapping and de-trapping by Fe3+ and Fe4+ ions reduce the probability of charge carrier recombination as revealed by photo luminescence spectroscopy and further promote charge migration and interfacial charge transfer. The catalysts display significant activity for photo catalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (PCRC) in aqueous alkaline medium, with methanol as major product. Synergetic effect due to co-doping of LNTO with Fe and N improves visible light absorption, retards recombination of charge carriers and thus helps to enhance PCRC activity by nearly three times vis-à-vis pristine NaTaO3. Keywords Visible light active sodium tantalate Co-doping with N and Fe Band gap engineering Synergetic effect CO2 photo reduction 1 Introduction Metal oxides and mixed metal oxides as versatile catalysts for various conversion processes have been explored extensively [1–3]. Of recent, application of metal oxides like TiO2 as photo catalysts in energy conversion and environment control processes has gained global attention, especially, for removal of pollutants in gaseous and liquid streams, hydrogen production by splitting of water and reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons [4]. CO2 emissions from the burning of fossil fuels pose serious environmental issues like green-house gas effect and unusual weather patterns [5]. Conversion of CO2 into fuels/hydrocarbons by utilizing photo catalytic routes is an effective strategy that can provide solution to the two key challenges, meeting energy demand and mitigating green house gas effect, besides exploring the scope for utilization of CO2 as alternative and renewable energy source. Photo catalytic reduction of CO2 (PCRC) into fuels/hydrocarbons or artificial photosynthesis, using water as the reductant, is a complex, multi-step and challenging process. Several investigations focusing on metal oxides like TiO2 and a wide range of mixed metal oxides as catalysts have been reported for the artificial photo synthesis [6–11]. Essential criteria for selection of catalysts for PCRC have been brought out explicitly by Inoue et al. [12]. In addition, longer life time of the photo generated charge carriers and shorter diffusion path length of excitons to the catalyst surface, where redox reactions occur, are the other desirable parameters that maximize the efficiency of the photo catalysts. Tantalum based perovskite materials of the type ATaO3 (A=Li, Na, K) possess requisite photo physical properties for photo catalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction [13–21]. Even though La modified NaTaO3 is highly efficient (quantum yield-56% with UV light) for water splitting [13,14], its application is limited to UV region due to its wide band gap, which absorbs only <5% of solar energy. To this end, engineering the band gap of NaTaO3 to improve visible light absorption by doping with cations and anions have been studied in detail [17–38], mainly for the application in photo catalytic splitting of water. Influence of doping/band gap engineering of NaTaO3 towards activity for PCRC has not been explored so far. Earlier studies on LaxNa(1−x)TaO(3+y) or LNTO by the authors have highlighted the role of co-catalysts like Pt, Ag, Au, CuO, NiO & RuO2 [20] and application of visible light harvesting sensitizers like porphyrins [21] in improving the overall activity for PCRC. As a part of our studies to improve the PCRC activity of LNTO, we now have undertaken investigations on the influence of doping/co-doping on the structural, morphological, electronic states and photo physical properties of the tantalate and understand their relevance to the activity for PCRC. Choice of dopants in the present work is based on the crystallographic and electronic structures of NaTaO3. Conduction band of tantalates is mainly made up of Ta 5d orbitals. A downward shift in the conduction band can be achieved by doping metal ion with lower energy orbital (3d, 4d) like Fe3+ at Ta5+ site. Simultaneously, presence of La3+ and Na+, could help to maintain the cationic charge balance in the tantalate lattice (Na+ +Ta5+ =La3+ +Fe3+). Studies have demonstrated that the modification of NaTaO3 by doping with Bi [19,20], Fe [21], Sr [22], Cu [27]. N [28–31] and co-doping with La-Cr [32,33], La-Co [34], La-Fe [35], La-Ir [36], La-N [37] promote its photo catalytic activity in the visible region. Valence band maximum (VBM) of NaTaO3 is formed mainly by O 2p orbitals. Upward shift of VBM can be achieved by doping with anions having energy higher than that for oxygen [28–31]. Wang et al. [38] have demonstrated the effect of doping with different anions like N, S, C, P and co-doping with NN, CS, PP and NP pairs on NaTaO3 on the basis of theoretical calculations and have shown that N doped NaTaO3 shifts VBM towards more positive energy level as compared to pristine and other anion doped NaTaO3 and towards more positive energy level with respect to the reduction potential for O2 as well, to produce H2 and O2. Since both N [38] and Fe [25,39,40] are considered to be the most effective anionic and cationic dopants respectively, co-doping of LNTO with Fe and N would be a more effective strategy to achieve reduction in the band gap energy, increase in the efficiency of the photo catalyst by improving visible light absorption and decreasing recombination rate of charge carriers. Thus, the synergetic influence of co-doping LNTO with N and Fe on the properties has been studied in detail and correlated with the activity for PCRC. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Preparation of catalysts NaTaO3 and 2.0% (w/w) cation/anion doped catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal route [41,42]. La modified NaTaO3, (Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) with x=0.00014 for 2.0% w/w of La) was prepared by the same procedure, by adding 0.0117g of La2O3 along with NaOH and Ta2O5 in the autoclave. 2wt% La, 2wt% Fe, 2mole of N modified NaTaO3 (Na(1−x) LaxTa(1−y)FeyO(3−z)Nz) was prepared by the same procedure, by adding La2O3 as La source, Fe2O3 as Fe source, urea as N source along with NaOH and Ta2O5. La doped NaTaO3 (Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x)) denoted as LNTO, N doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) as N/LNTO, Fe doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) as Fe/LNTO and Fe and N co-doped Na(1−x) LaxTaO(3+x) as Fe-N/LNTO in further discussions. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The crystal phase of the catalysts was analysed by X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku-MiniFlex-II) using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å) with the scan range of 2θ=5−90° at a speed of 3°/min. The crystallite sizes were calculated by the Scherrer’s formula, t=Kλ/β cosθ, where t is the crystallite size, K is the constant dependent on crystallite shape (0.9 for this case) and λ =1.54056Å, β is the FWHM (full width at half maximum) and θ is the Bragg’s angle. Diffuse reflectance spectra of the catalysts in the UV–vis region were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Evolution 600 spectrophotometer equipped with a Praying Mantis diffuse reflectance accessory. Photoluminescence spectra were recorded under the excitation with a 450W Xenon lamp at 290nm and the spectra were collected using Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3-11 spectro fluorimeter. Surface area and pore volume of the catalysts were measured using Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Samples were degassed at 373K for 2hours and at 423K for 3hours. Pure nitrogen at liquid nitrogen temperature (77K) was used. Transmission electron micrographs were recorded using JEOL 3010 model. Few milligrams of the samples (1–2mg) were dispersed in few mL (1–2mL) of ethanol by ultra-sonication for 15minutes and a drop of the dispersion was placed on a carbon coated copper grid and allowed to dry in air at room temperature. Scanning electron micrographs were recorded using FEI, Quanta 200, equipped with EDXA attachment for elemental analysis. The samples in the powder form were taken on the carbon tape and mounted on the SEM sample holder. The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the catalysts were recorded using Omicron Nanotechnology instrument with Mg Kα radiation. The base pressure of the analysis chamber during the scan was 2×10−10 millibar. The pass energies for individual scan and survey scan are 20 and 100eV, respectively. The spectra were recorded with step width of 0.05eV. The data were processed with the Casa XPS program (Casa Software Ltd, UK), and calibrated with reference to the adventitious carbon peak (284.9eV) in the sample. Peak areas were determined by integration employing a Shirley-type background. Peaks were considered to be a 70:30 mix of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions. The relative sensitivity factors (RSF) were obtained from literature. 2.3 Photo catalytic reduction of CO2 Activity of the catalysts in UV visible region (300–700nm) was evaluated in batch mode using jacketed all glass reactor (620ml) described in the earlier work [43]. Apparent quantum yield (AQY) was calculated (Supporting information- Experimental) based on the quantities of different products formed per hour per gram of the catalyst and using the formula A Q Y ( % ) = N u m b e r o f r e a c t e d e l e c t r o n s N u m b e r o f i n c i d e n t p r o t o n s × 100 Details on the procedures and methods followed for evaluation of PCRC activity of the catalysts the blank experiments and removal of residual carbon the catalyst surface have been described elsewhere [20,21]. Details on the gas chromatographic analysis of the CO2 reduction products are given in Supplementary information-Experimental 3 Results and Discussion Doping of LNTO with N and Fe3+ brings about significant changes in the structural, morphological, electronic states and photo physical properties. These aspects are discussed in detail below. 3.1 Structural features XRD patterns for the synthesized materials are shown in Fig. 1 . Peaks at 2θ values of 22.9(020), 32.5(200), 40.1(022), 46.6(202), 52.4(301), 58.2(123) correspond to orthorhombic crystal structure (JCPDS Card No. 25-0863) of NaTaO3. There is no significant change in XRD patterns with La modified as well as catalysts doped/co-doped with N & Fe. No diffraction peaks related to La2O3, Fe2O3, Ta2O5 were found. This is possibly due to low concentration of dopant elements and/or at least a part of dopant element has been incorporated into the NaTaO3 lattice, especially with the ionic radii of the dopants, ie, Fe3+ and La3+ being closer to Ta5+ and Na+ respectively. As reported in literature [13,35,44] substitution of A site cation Na+ (1.39Å) by La3+ (1.36Å in12 coordinated octahedral site) and B site cation Ta5+ (0.64Å) by Fe3+ (0.65Å in 6 fold coordinated site) in the ABO3 crystal lattice of NaTaO3 resulted in small shift in d-lines, as shown in Fig. S1. Crystallite sizes of the synthesized photo catalysts were calculated by the Scherer’s formula. Doping with Fe maintains the cationic charge balance (Na+ +Ta5+ =La3+ +Fe3+) in the lattice [35], and hence less crystal defects are expected, compared LNTO or pristine NaTaO3. Calculated lattice parameters shown in Table 1 indicate small changes due to distortion of the lattice brought about by the dopants. Surface area of Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) as measured by BET method was 2.9m2/g and no significant changes in the textural properties were observed with the other doped NaTaO3. 3.2 Electronic properties DRS spectra in UV–vis region for pristine and modified NaTaO3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The onset of absorption edge for the pristine NaTaO3 (curve b) is at 318nm, ie absorption only in the Ultra Violet region, with a band gap of 3.9eV [13]. Addition of La3+ to form Na(1−x) Lax TaO(3+x) shifts the absorption edge on higher energy side (curve a), with a band gap of 4.1eV [14]. DR spectra for NaTaO3 catalysts, doped with N and Fe individually and together, on the contrary, showed red shift, towards visible region (curves c–e). In pristine NaTaO3, VBM is mainly composed of O 2p orbitals, while CBM is mainly composed of Ta 5d orbitals. In the case of N doped LNTO, N 2p orbital energy level is higher than that of O 2p (VBM) orbital energy level and hence, 2p orbitals of doped N are situated at the top of the VBM as impurity state [28–31]. The observed narrow band gap (3.5eV) with N doped photo catalyst (Fig. 2d, Table 1) can be ascribed due to the electron transition from impurity states (O 2p+N 2p) to the bottom of the B of LNTO [29,37,38]. A steep increase of the absorption at λ>390nm with Fe doped catalyst, is ascribed to the electron excitation of 3d e- of Fe3+ to CBM of LNTO and the prominent peak at 590nm was also observed with Fe doped NaTaO3. Similar absorption peak in Fe doped NaTaO3 was observed in the earlier reports [25,35], which could be due to d-d transition 2T2g →2A2g, 2T1g of Fe3+ or charge transfer transition between iron ions (Fe3+ +Fe3+ →Fe4+ +Fe2+) [45,46]. While doping only with Fe3+ on La-NaTaO3 results in band gap reduction to 3.1eV, co-doping with N & Fe3+ reduces the band gap further to 2.6eV, due to synergetic effect. 3.3 Compositional and Morphological features Morphology and elemental composition of the synthesized catalysts have been established by SEM and EDXA studies. Figs. Fig. 3 a and Fig. 4 a show SEM images for the neat NaTaO3 and Fe-N/Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) modified catalysts. Cubic morphology of pristine NaTaO3 is retained in all the doped catalysts. TEM (Fig. 5 a & b) further confirms the cubic morphology of the Na(1−x) Lax TaO(3+x) and Fe-N/Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) respectively. SAED (Fig. 5c) shows the highly crystalline nature of NaTaO3 nano cubes, and d-value of 0.389nm measured from HRTEM (Fig. 5d) corresponds to (002) planes of orthorhombic phase of NaTaO3. The presence of added dopants in the tantalate matrix is confirmed by EDXA measurements. Figs. Fig. 3b and Fig. 4b show EDXA spectra for neat and Fe-N/Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) catalysts respectively. Presence of dopants such as Fe, N, La implies that the elements have been effectively incorporated into the tantalate matrix during hydrothermal reaction. STEM-EDS elemental mapping of Na(Kα), Ta(Lα), La(Lα), Fe(Kα), O(Kα) and N(Kα) presented in Fig. S2 for the Fe-N/Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) photo catalyst, further confirms the uniform distribution of dopant elements in the tantalate matrix. 3.4 Chemical states of dopants by XPS analysis XPS measurements were carried out to analyse chemical composition and chemical states of the doped elements present in the synthesized photo catalysts. Typical XPS survey spectra for the synthesized photo catalysts are shown in Fig. S3. Binding energy (BE) values for the main XPS peaks for elements identified in the synthesized materials are tabulated in Table 2a , and surface chemical composition of the identified elements in Table 2b . High resolution spectra of Na 1s, Ta 4d and O 1s present in the neat and modified photo catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . Main peaks for Na 1s (1071eV), Ta 4d (229.6eV) and O 1s (529.5eV) were observed in pristine NaTaO3 and similar peaks with small shifts in binding energy (BE) were observed for the modified catalysts. The shifts in BE can be ascribed to the slight distortion of the NaTaO3 lattice brought out by the doped elements. Two types of O 1s peak are observed in all the neat and modified catalysts. The peak centered at 529eV corresponds to lattice oxygen of Ta-O-Ta in octahedral TaO6 crystal lattice and the other small area peak centered at 531eV can be ascribed to surface hydroxyl group or adsorbed oxygen. Fig. 7 A shows high resolution XP spectra for La 4d, wherein the peak centered at 834.6eV corresponds to La3+ ion, indicating that the dopant is incorporated into the tantalate lattice, with ionic radii of La3+ (1.36Å) and Na+ (1.39Å) ions being closer [37,45,47]. High resolution XP spectra for Fe 2p shown in Fig. 8 B, displays a peak centered at 711.9eV due to the dopant Fe present as Fe3+ ion (Table 2a). Presence of Ta5+ ions around Fe3+ ions in the lattice results in a shift in the BE to 711.9eV, compared to 710.7eV observed for Fe3+ in precursor Fe2O3 [48]. The shift in BE is due to the interaction between Fe3+ and Ta5+ ions in crystal lattice, which clearly shows that some of the doped Fe3+ ions have been incorporated into TaO6 crystal lattice. Since ionic radii of Ta5+ and Fe3+ ions are closer, Fe3+ ions occupy Ta5+ ion sites in the lattice. N 1s spectrum for N doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) sample (Fig. 8A - profile a) shows two peaks, one centered at 398.1eV corresponding to substitutional N species, ie., representing Ta-N linkages and another peak centered at 399.9eV, corresponding to interstitial nitrogen (Ta-O-N) or adsorption of nitride on the N modified photo catalyst surface (Table 2a). Similarly, N 1s spectrum for N & Fe co-doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) (Fig. 8A - profile b) also displays two peaks at 398.3eV and 399.8 indicating the presence of two types of surface nitrogen species. The above results are consistent with the earlier literature reports [29–31,49,50]. The observed N 1s spectra for N doped and N and Fe co-doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) implies that some of the oxygen sites are substituted by doped nitrogen atoms as N3− and some of the nitrogen in the interstitial position in the crystal lattice of NaTaO3. As reported by Zhao et al., synergetic effect of La-N co doping also promotes the incorporation of nitrogen into the lattice [37]. High resolution XP spectra for Ta 4f levels in N doped and N and Fe co-doped Na(1−x)LaxTaO(3+x) samples are shown in Fig. 7B (profiles a & b respectively). The peaks centered at 25.5 and 27.5eV correspond to Ta 4f7/2 and Ta 4f5/2 levels respectively (Table 2a). It is seen from Table 2a that, with respect to the Ta 4f7/2 peak for pristine NaTaO3, the corresponding peaks for La modified, N doped, Fe doped and N and Fe co-doped samples are shifted to lower binding energy side, indicating the effect of doping on the electronic state of Ta5+ ions. The shift in BE on N doping can be ascribed to the formation of Ta-N bond in N doped NaTaO3 photo catalyst. According to Hara et al. [50], TaO bond is less covalent than TaN bond, and hence dopant nitrogen increases electron density around Ta, consequently lowering BE [29,51]. Binding energy shift towards lower side of Ta 4f peaks further confirms the incorporation of doped nitrogen into oxygen sites of NaTaO3 lattice. Doping with Fe and co-doping with N and Fe also shifts Ta 4f peak to lower binding energy side (Table 2a). 3.5 Photo physical properties Photoluminescence spectra for the neat and modified catalysts (Fig. 9 ) give additional features of the doped catalysts. An emission peak, centred at 469nm is observed for the neat and modified NaTaO3, demonstrating that doping of the photo catalyst does not result in any new PL spectral line, but the intensity of the line is reduced. PL spectra mainly result from the recombination of charge carriers and its intensity is directly proportional to the probability of the recombination of charge carriers. When the pristine catalyst was doped with La and N separately, the intensity of the PL spectral line is reduced significantly, in steps. Further reduction in the intensity of the PL spectral line is observed, when the pristine catalyst is doped with Fe. On co-doping with Fe and N, another significant reduction in intensity is observed. Decrease in the intensity of the PL line implies that dopant (Fe or N) or co-dopants (Fe and N) could reduce the probability of recombination of the charge carriers, leading to an increase the life time of the charge carriers. 3.6 Photo catalytic reduction of CO2 Progress of CO2 reduction process was followed for 20hrs on all catalysts. Trends in the formation of major products, methanol and ethanol, with respect to time of irradiation up to 20hrs, are given in Fig. 10 . Besides hydrogen and oxygen, methane, ethylene and ethane were formed in very small quantities (∼0.1–10 micromoles/g) and hence not considered in the plots. CO and formic acid were detected at trace levels and hence could not be quantified. As shown in Fig. S4, large amounts of methanol is formed when the aqueous alkaline solution is saturated with carbon dioxide compared to very small quantities formed after saturation with nitrogen, indicating that the observed methanol/products were obtained from CO2 photo reduction, not from surface carbon impurities on the catalyst. Comparison of the two major products (methanol and ethanol) formed on neat NaTaO3 (Fig. 10a) and Fe-N-LNTO (Fig. 10b) clearly brings about the improvement in activity due to co-doping with Fe and N on LNTO. The individual roles played by the three dopants, La, Fe and N in improving the activity, in terms of their photo-physical properties, have been elaborated in the following section. Rates of formation of products are high during initial 8–10hrs, beyond which the product formation tends to slow down. Based on the initial rates (μmolg−1 h−1) for the formation of different products, and the number of photo electrons involved in each case, apparent quantum yields (AQY) for all the photo catalysts have been calculated and presented in Table 3 . 3.7 Role of dopants- La, N and Fe It is observed from Table 3 that iron and nitrogen doping in LNTO significantly influences the overall quantum yield as well as selectivity to various products. Doping of lanthanum separately to NaTaO3, results in marginal increase in quantum yield. Substantial increase in activity is observed by doping separately with N or Fe. However, in the case of LNTO co-doped with N and Fe, quantum yield increased by nearly three times, with respect to neat NaTaO3. Fe-N/LNTO photo catalyst displays maximum increase in activity and relatively higher selectivity towards alcohols. Comparison of different hydrocarbon formation after 20hrs of irradiation (cumulative) with various synthesized photo catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . Total hydrocarbon products formed on Fe and N co-doped LNTO is three times than that formed on neat NaTaO3 Doping with La, N and Fe separately does promote CO2 photo reduction but are not as effective as Fe and N co doped photo catalyst. With an increase in the band gap value (3.9–4.1eV) on lanthanum doping, the conduction band energy level becomes more negative with respect to that for pristine NaTaO3. Higher conduction band energy level vis-à-vis CO2 reduction potential increases the CO2 reduction efficiency [20,52] Besides, the intensity of the photo luminescence line for LNTO is less than that for pristine NaTaO3, indicating that the recombination of charge carriers is retarded. These two factors result in increase in activity towards CO2 reduction due to La doping. Since the dopant Fe 3d orbital energy level is smaller than Ta 5d orbital, it will create new energy level below the conduction band resulting in downward shift of CB [25] as shown in Fig. 12 . As evident from the XRD and XPS data, Fe3+ ion occupies Ta5+ site in the lattice. Dopant Fe3+ ion possesses the ability to trap and de-trap the charge carriers, ie, Fe3+ ion can easily trap photo generated electrons from the CB of NaTaO3, since dopant energy level for electron trapping, ie., Fe3+/Fe2+ (0.77V vs NHE) is below the CBM of NaTaO3 (−1.06V vs NHE). Also, Fe3+ can easily trap photo generated holes from VB NaTaO3 since dopant energy level for hole trapping ie Fe4+/Fe3+ (2.2V vs NHE) is above the VB of NaTaO3 (2.94V vs NHE). The above characteristic nature of Fe3+ would help to enhance the charge carrier life time, as is evident from fluorescence spectra (Fig. 9) [40,53]. De-trapping of excitons (charge release and migration) is also important factor as far as photo catalysis concerned, because trapped excitons have to reach surface adsorbed species to get converted into useful products. Fe could promote such interfacial charge transfer, as proposed for titania doped with Fe [40,54]. According to crystal field theory, Fe3+ is the most stable form of Fe because of its d5 electronic configuration. Hence, as mentioned above, Fe4+ and Fe2+ ions have the tendency to release their trapped charges to surface adsorbed species to become most stable Fe3+ [40,45]. As observed from XPS data, doped La as La3+ can easily diffuse into perovskite lattice and cationic charge is maintained by Fe3+ doping at Ta5+ site and La3+ at Na+ site [Na+ +Ta5+ →La3+ +Fe3+], which will reduce defect sites [35]. Synergetic effect of La-N co-doping also reduces the point defects [37], which is beneficial since the defect sites, could otherwise serve as a charge recombination centres. As revealed by DRS studies, doping with nitrogen improves visible light absorption of NaTaO3 and hence the activity. Thus, increase in photo catalytic activity with La-N-Fe co-doped NaTaO3 can be ascribed due to the following improvements in the photo-physical characteristics of the doped formulations, namely, a) increase in absorption of light energy in the visible region, b) longer life time of charge carriers and c) promotion of interfacial charge transfer, as explained earlier. The changes in the electronic energy levels taking place when doping with La, N and Fe separately and co-doping with Fe and N are depicted in Fig. 12. These changes are in line with the experimental values for band gap energy measured by DRS UV spectra (Fig. 2). 3.8 Analysis of used catalysts After 20hrs of reaction, the used catalyst was centrifuged, dried and pre-treated at 573K in air for 3hrs and characterized by XRD and SEM studies. As shown in Fig. S5a and 5b,the perovskite structure and cubic morphology of the tantalate have been retained, indicating the stability of the catalyst. SEM for used catalyst indicates slight surface attrition due to continuous agitation. 4 Conclusions Neat and doped/co-doped NaTaO3 modified with lanthana (LNTO) have been synthesized by simple one step hydrothermal method. The effect of doping/co-doping LNTO with N and Fe on the photo physical properties of the catalysts has been investigated by applying a range of experimental techniques. XRD and XPS results reveal that La3+ occupies Na+ ion sites, Fe3+ ions Ta5+ ions site and N the O2− sites, possibly as N3− in the tantalate matrix. Incorporation of the dopants in the tantalate matrix has been confirmed by SEM-EDXA and STEM-EDS elemental mapping and surface composition analysis by XPS. La, Fe and N co-doping in tantalate matrix results in the narrowing of the band gap due to the creation of additional energy levels within the band gap and consequently, visible light absorption. Presence of dopants in the lattice ensures electro-neutrality. The catalysts display significant activity for photo catalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (PCRC) in aqueous alkaline medium, with methanol as major product. Efficient charge trapping and de-trapping by Fe3+ and Fe4+ ions reduces the probability of charge carrier recombination. Synergetic effect due to co-doping of LNTO with Fe and N improves visible light absorption, retards recombination of charge carriers and promotes interfacial charge transfer, thus helping to enhance PCRC activity by nearly three times vis-à-vis pristine NaTaO3. Acknowledgement Authors gratefully acknowledge the Department of Science & Technology, Govt. of India for the grant towards establishing NCCR at IIT Madras and M/s Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited, Mumbai for a funding the project on photo catalytic conversion of CO2. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2017.11.021. coredata.dc:description: Sodium tantalate (NaTaO3), a typical mixed metal oxide with orthorhombic structure, has been modified by incorporation of lanthana (LaxNa(1−x)TaO(3+y) or LNTO), followed by doping/co-doping with N and Fe3+, with the objective of improving visible light absorption and photo physical properties. XRD and XPS results reveal that La3+ occupies Na+ ion sites, Fe3+ ions Ta5+ ion sites and N the O2− ion sites, possibly as N3− in the tantalate matrix. Incorporation of the dopants in the tantalate matrix has been confirmed by SEM-EDXA and STEM-EDS elemental mapping and surface composition analysis by XPS. Fe and N co-doping in tantalate matrix results in the narrowing of the band gap due to the creation of additional energy levels within the band gap and consequently, visible light absorption. Presence of Fe3+ and La3+ dopants in the tantalate lattice ensures electro-neutrality. Efficient charge trapping and de-trapping by Fe3+ and Fe4+ ions reduce the probability of charge carrier recombination as revealed by photo luminescence spectroscopy and further promote charge migration and interfacial charge transfer. The catalysts display significant activity for photo catalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (PCRC) in aqueous alkaline medium, with methanol as major product. Synergetic effect due to co-doping of LNTO with Fe and N improves visible light absorption, retards recombination of charge carriers and thus helps to enhance PCRC activity by nearly three times vis-à-vis pristine NaTaO3.
coredata.dc:title: Metal oxides as photo catalysts: Modified sodium tantalate as catalyst for photo reduction of carbon dioxide
coredata.prism:issueName: Metal Oxides in Catalysis - Professor Benjaram M. Reddy Festschrift
